content:
Dear category theorists,

Let VVV be a monoidal cartesian category (not necessarily closed or complete). I am looking for a simple description of a notion of "VVV-enriched terminal object" and "VVV-enriched binary cartesian product", if such things exist. Following this answer, if CCC is a VVV-enriched category, one can use the cartesianness of the enriching base VVV to define VVV-functors

C ⟶ 1andC ⟶ C×CC \ \longrightarrow\ 1 \qquad\text{and}\qquad C \ \longrightarrow\ C \times CC ⟶ 1andC ⟶ C×C

which makes it possible to ask for these functors to have VVV-right adjoints. This specializes to the usual notions when V=SetV = \mathbf{Set}V=Set, but I have not found this written down in a paper.

I am aware that the interesting concept of weighted limit is central in enriched category theory, and that it provides the right notion of limit for the enriched setting, but I am looking for references which spell out in accessible terms what are enriched finite cartesian products. I have the impression that this should be a very simple example -- and enriched cartesian products are even mentioned on the nlab page for enriched CCCs -- yet I can't find such a reference.

Do anyone know a reference that I could cite? or is this notion more complicated than I thought, and perhaps that there are multiple, non-equivalent generalizations to the enriched setting? or something else?

FWIW, I would follow a similar path and define a "object with Cartesian product" in a (V,×,1)(V,\times,1)(V,×,1)-category as a CCC such that C→1C\to 1C→1 and C→C×CC\to C\times CC→C×C both have a right adjoint.

fosco said:

FWIW, I would follow a similar path and define a "object with Cartesian product" in a (V,×,1)(V,\times,1)(V,×,1)-category as a CCC such that C→1C\to 1C→1 and C→C×CC\to C\times CC→C×C both have a right adjoint.

Did you meant in V-CatV\text{-}\mathbf{Cat}V-Cat? Then this coincides with the notion of cartesian object, and as stated in my message I think this should give a good notion of cartesian VVV-category, when VVV is cartesian monoidal.

What puzzles me is that I cannot find a place in the literature which introduces cartesian VVV-categories, in this way or another, and not even the notion of enriched terminal object.

Street defines the notion of cartesian V-category in section 3 of Kan extensions and cartesian monoidal categories even when V is not cartesian. However, it's not immediately clear to me that there necessarily exists a class of weights Φ\PhiΦ for which a V-category is Φ\PhiΦ-complete if and only if it is cartesian in this sense.
Isn't this just the case of "conical" VVV-limits (section 3.8 in Kelly's book) when the domain ordinary category is empty or is 222?

Nathanael Arkor said:

Street defines the notion of cartesian V-category in section 3 of Kan extensions and cartesian monoidal categories even when V is not cartesian. However, it's not immediately clear to me that there necessarily exists a class of weights Φ\PhiΦ for which a V-category is Φ\PhiΦ-complete if and only if it is cartesian in this sense.

I like the generality of this approach, but I have a naive question: in the case of plain categories, being cartesian is a property, as this boils down to the diagonal functor having a right adjoint, which is unique up to iso if it exists. In the enriched case described in the article you have linked, we only ask for the given VVV-enriched functor C⊗C→CC \otimes C \to CC⊗C→C to have a left adjoint, whatever it is. Therefore, I am not sure if two such "cartesian monoidal" structures on the same VVV-enriched category must always be the same, for the appropriate notion of sameness, given that we don't have a common left adjoint to compare them.

Mike Shulman said:

Isn't this just the case of "conical" VVV-limits (section 3.8 in Kelly's book) when the domain ordinary category is empty or is 222?

Perhaps this coincides with the description given in terms of enriched right adjoints to the functor into the terminal enriched category and the diagonal functor, I don't know. I'm trying to see if there is a reference which defines such a notion of cartesian enriched category for a cartesian monoidal base, which I could cite. Perhaps this is folklore?

Vincent Moreau said:

Therefore, I am not sure if two such "cartesian monoidal" structures on the same VVV-enriched category must always be the same, for the appropriate notion of sameness, given that we don't have a common left adjoint to compare them.

That's true; cartesianness is a property of a specific monoidal structure in this setting.
This is interesting, how do you see that?

Sorry, my phrasing was unclear. I meant that you're right that being "cartesian" is a property of a given monoidal category, rather than a given category. So prima facie there may be two different monoidal structures on a V-category, both of which are cartesian, but which are not related.
Ah sorry, I see!

Vincent Moreau said:

Perhaps this coincides with the description given in terms of enriched right adjoints to the functor into the terminal enriched category and the diagonal functor, I don't know.

I think it does coincide, at least under the assumption free V-categories on ordinary categories exists. Without that assumption, one can still use Kelly's explicit definition of "conical limit" (which gives the universal property you're looking for), but it's no longer necessarily a special kind of weighted limit, as far as I can see.
OK, well I cannot really afford to have a cocomplete enriching base so I'm going to dive into section 3.8 and try to work it out. Thanks!
For what it's worth, the definition as a cartesian object in V-Cat appears as Definition 3.9 of Modality via Iterated Enrichment.
Indeed, thanks!
If VVV isn't cocomplete then I think you can just work with V^\widehat{V}V-categories and their weighted limits.

Nathanael Arkor said:

Sorry, my phrasing was unclear. I meant that you're right that being "cartesian" is a property of a given monoidal category, rather than a given category. So prima facie there may be two different monoidal structures on a V-category, both of which are cartesian, but which are not related.

I've thought a bit about that. Suppose for the moment that we work in V=SetV = \mathbf{Set}V=Set, and that (C,⊗,I)(C, \otimes, I)(C,⊗,I) is a locally small monoidal category which is cartesian in the sense of this article of Street. This means that III is terminal and that we have an adjunction

?:C ⇄ C2:⊗? \quad:\quad C \ \rightleftarrows\ C^2 \quad:\quad \otimes?:C ⇄ C2:⊗

with ⊗\otimes⊗ the right adjoint. A priori, we don't know anything on the functor ???, and especially not that it is the diagonal functor. But now, we compose this with the adjunction

π1:C2 ⇄ C:(−,I)\pi_1 \quad:\quad C^2 \ \rightleftarrows\ C \quad:\quad (-, I)π1​:C2 ⇄ C:(−,I)

where the right adjoint is the functor c↦(c,I)c \mapsto (c, I)c↦(c,I).

But now, thanks to the fact that III is the monoidal unit, the composite of the two right adjoints is isomorphic to the identity endofunctor of CCC, whereas the composite of the two left adjoints is the functor

c↦π1(?(c)):C ⟶ C2 ⟶ Cc \mapsto \pi_1(?(c)) \quad:\quad C \ \longrightarrow\ C^2 \ \longrightarrow\ Cc↦π1​(?(c)):C ⟶ C2 ⟶ C

which is then isomorphic to the identity endofunctor. By doing this story again with π2\pi_2π2​, we get that the mysterious left adjoint ??? is actually the diagonal.
If all of this is correct, then this means that this notion of monoidal cartesian enriched category used by Street boils down to the usual notion when we enrich in sets, which is a nice thing!

I'm not fluent enough in enriched categories to assert that this extends to the enriched case, but I wouldn't be shocked if it does in the case where the enriching base VVV is cartesian, which makes it possible to have a terminal VVV-category and hence to talk about the πi\pi_iπi​.

Vincent Moreau said:

If all of this is correct, then this means that this notion of monoidal cartesian enriched category used by Street boils down to the usual notion when we enrich in sets, which is a nice thing!

Street explains why it recovers the usual definition for V = Set, but I don't see that Street's definition should coincide with a cartesian object in V-Cat when V is not cartesian monoidal (meaning the tensor product is the cartesian product, not simply that V has finite products).
Sadly I don't understand where Street explains this
In any case, I have some hope for the proof above to hold in the case of VVV-enriched categories for VVV cartesian monoidal
Yes, I think it goes through fine in that case.

Vincent Moreau said:

Sadly I don't understand where Street explains this

image.png
Here, he shows that the tensor product of the monoidal V-category in question satisfies this universal property, and when V is cartesian monoidal, this is the universal property of a product.
But I think your argument is also clear.

Nathanael Arkor said:

image.png
Here, he shows that the tensor product of the monoidal V-category in question satisfies this universal property, and when V is cartesian monoidal, this is the universal property of a product.

I understand that A\mathscr{A}A is endowed with a comonoidal structure, which when passed to the monoidal functor ob from VVV-Cat to Set yields a comonoid, hence the fact that Δ\DeltaΔ is the diagonal on objects. I understand too that the naturality of the isomorphisms in your screenshot is formulated with Δ\DeltaΔ in its AAA variable. However, does this show that Δ\DeltaΔ is isomorphic to the diagonal functor in the case where VVV is cartesian monoidal? This I don't see.

I suppose that this is what the conical limit defining products that you and Mike were referring to boils down to, by the way?

When V is cartesian monoidal, the tensor product of V-categories is also cartesian, and so every V-category has a unique comonoid structure with respect to the tensor product. Thus Δ\DeltaΔ is not just the diagonal on objects, but also on morphisms.
Right, of course! Thanks for the explanation, Nathanael :)

I feel like the name "cartesian monoidal enriched category" for this thing is kind of misleading when VVV is noncartesian. I would expect a "cartesian monoidal category" to always be one where the monoidal product is the cartesian product, i.e. adjoint to the standard diagonal A→A×AA\to A\times AA→A×A, not adjoint to some other "diagonal" A→A⊗AA\to A\otimes AA→A⊗A that's given as extra data. I would be inclined to give this a name with something like "Hopf" in it.
It's a "comap pseudomonoid" following the terminology of Day and Street.
I suppose.
